dublinCore.dc:title: 117 HR 6730 IH: Protecting Higher Education from the Chinese Communist Party Act of 2022
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mrs. Hartzler (for herself, Mr. Balderson, and Mr. Mast) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To make certain members of the Chinese Communist Party ineligible for F or J visas, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Protecting Higher Education from the Chinese Communist Party Act of 2022.

section.header: Ineligibility for certain visas of members of the Chinese Communist Party

subsection.text: An alien may not be accorded status or receive a visa under subparagraph (F) or (J) of section 101(a)(15) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1101(a)(15)) if the alien is a person who is, as of the date of enactment of this Act or at any time thereafter—

paragraph.text: a member of the Chinese Communist Party (hereinafter referred to as the CCP) who has served on the National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party or other position, including—

subparagraph.text: a member of the Secretariat of the CCP;
a member of the Political Bureau Standing Committee;
a member of the Political Bureau of the CCP Central Committee;
a member of the CCP Central Committee;
a member of the Central Military Commission;
a member of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection; or
a member of the National People’s Congress; or

paragraph.text: a family member of a person described in paragraph (1).

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, the term family member means, with respect to a person, that person’s spouse, child, parent, sibling, or grandchild.

subsection.header: Exception To comply with United Nations Headquarters Agreement
subsection.text: Subsection (a) shall not apply to an individual if admitting the individual to the United States is necessary to permit the United States to comply with the Agreement between the United Nations and the United States of America regarding the Headquarters of the United Nations, signed June 26, 1947, and entered into force November 21, 1947, and other applicable international obligations.

The President, or a designee of the President, may waive the application of subsection (a) if the President or such designee certifies in writing to the appropriate congressional committees that such waiver is in the national security interest of the United States.
